messages.content:
Your task is to summarize a tool call & response pair to save tokens

reply with a single message that describe what happened. Typically a toolcall
is asks for something using a bunch of parameters and then the result is also some
structured output. So the tool might ask to look up something on github and the
reply might be a json document. So you could reply with something like:

"A call to github was made to get the project status"

if that is what it was.

[assistant]: tool_request(developer__text_editor): {"path":"/workspace/SPEC.md","command":"view","view_range":null}
[user]: tool_response: ### /workspace/SPEC.md
```markdown
1: # Product Requirements Document: To-Do List Application with React Frontend and Spring Boot Backend
2: 
3: ## Overview
4: This project implements a simple to-do list application. The backend is built using Spring Boot, providing a REST API for managing to-do items. The frontend is built using React, providing a user interface for interacting with the API. To-do items are stored in memory (ephemeral). Each to-do item includes a description, due date, priority, and category.
5: 
6: ## Goals
7: - User can add a new to-do item with a description, due date, priority, and category via the React UI.
8: - User can view a list of all to-do items in the React UI.
9: - User can mark a to-do item as complete via the React UI.
10: - User can delete a to-do item via the React UI.
11: - The Spring Boot backend provides a REST API to support the React UI functionality.
12: 
13: ## Non-Goals
14: - User authentication and authorization.
15: - Persistent storage of to-do items (e.g., using a database).
16: - Advanced filtering or sorting of to-do items.
17: - User accounts or profiles.
18: - Real-time updates (e.g., using WebSockets).
19: 
20: ## Components
21: 
22: ### ToDoItem Model
23: **Responsibility:** Represents a to-do item with properties like description, due date, priority, category, and completion status.
24: 
25: **Affected Files:**
26: - `src/main/java/com/example/todolist/model/ToDoItem.java`
27: 
28: **Behavior Expectations:**
29: - The ToDoItem class should have fields for id (Long), description (String), dueDate (LocalDate), priority (String), category (String), and completed (boolean).
30: - The ToDoItem class should have appropriate getters and setters for all fields.
31: - The ToDoItem class should have a constructor that accepts description, dueDate, priority, and category as arguments.
32: - Priority should be an enum with values HIGH, MEDIUM, LOW.
33: - Category should be a String.
34: 
35: **Integration Points:**
36: - Used by the ToDoService for creating, retrieving, updating, and deleting to-do items.
37: - Returned by the ToDoController as part of the REST API responses.
38: 
39: ### ToDoService
40: **Responsibility:** Provides the business logic for managing to-do items, including creating, retrieving, updating, and deleting them. Stores to-do items in an in-memory list.
41: 
42: **Affected Files:**
43: - `src/main/java/com/example/todolist/service/ToDoService.java`
44: 
45: **Behavior Expectations:**
46: - The ToDoService class should have methods for: - creating a new to-do item (createToDoItem) - retrieving all to-do items (getAllToDoItems) - retrieving a to-do item by ID (getToDoItemById) - updating a to-do item (updateToDoItem) - deleting a to-do item (deleteToDoItem)
47: - The ToDoService should use an in-memory list (ArrayList) to store the to-do items.
48: - The createToDoItem method should generate a unique ID for each new to-do item.
49: - The updateToDoItem method should update the properties of an existing to-do item.
50: - The deleteToDoItem method should remove a to-do item from the in-memory list.
51: - The getToDoItemById method should return null if no item with the given ID exists.
52: 
53: **Integration Points:**
54: - Used by the ToDoController to handle REST API requests.
55: - Uses the ToDoItem model to represent to-do items.
56: 
57: ### ToDoController
58: **Responsibility:** Handles REST API requests for managing to-do items.
59: 
60: **Affected Files:**
61: - `src/main/java/com/example/todolist/controller/ToDoController.java`
62: 
63: **Behavior Expectations:**
64: - The ToDoController should have endpoints for: - creating a new to-do item (POST /api/todos) - retrieving all to-do items (GET /api/todos) - retrieving a to-do item by ID (GET /api/todos/{id}) - updating a to-do item (PUT /api/todos/{id}) - deleting a to-do item (DELETE /api/todos/{id})
65: - The ToDoController should use the ToDoService to perform the business logic.
66: - The ToDoController should return appropriate HTTP status codes for each request (e.g., 200 OK, 201 Created, 404 Not Found).
67: - The ToDoController should serialize and deserialize ToDoItem objects to/from JSON.
68: - The POST /api/todos endpoint should return the created ToDoItem with its generated ID.
69: - The PUT /api/todos/{id} endpoint should return 404 if the item does not exist.
70: - The DELETE /api/todos/{id} endpoint should return 404 if the item does not exist.
71: 
72: **Integration Points:**
73: - Exposes the REST API for the React frontend.
74: - Uses the ToDoService to manage to-do items.
75: - Uses the ToDoItem model to represent to-do items.
76: 
77: ### React Frontend
78: **Responsibility:** Provides a user interface for interacting with the Spring Boot REST API to manage to-do items.
79: 
80: **Affected Files:**
81: - `src/main/js/App.js`
82: - `src/main/js/components/ToDoList.js`
83: - `src/main/js/components/ToDoItem.js`
84: - `src/main/js/components/ToDoForm.js`
85: 
86: **Behavior Expectations:**
87: - The App.js component should be the main entry point for the React application.
88: - The ToDoList.js component should display a list of to-do items retrieved from the API.
89: - The ToDoItem.js component should display a single to-do item and allow the user to mark it as complete or delete it.
90: - The ToDoForm.js component should allow the user to add a new to-do item.
91: - The React frontend should use the Fetch API or Axios to make requests to the Spring Boot REST API.
92: - The React frontend should handle errors gracefully (e.g., displaying an error message to the user).
93: - The React frontend should update the UI automatically when to-do items are added, updated, or deleted.
94: - The due date should be displayed in a user-friendly format.
95: - The priority should be displayed as High, Medium, or Low.
96: - The category should be displayed as a string.
97: 
98: **Integration Points:**
99: - Consumes the REST API exposed by the ToDoController.
100: - Displays to-do items to the user and allows them to interact with them.
101: 
102: ### Configuration
103: **Responsibility:** Configures the Spring Boot application, including setting the port and enabling CORS.
104: 
105: **Affected Files:**
106: - `src/main/java/com/example/todolist/config/WebConfig.java`
107: 
108: **Behavior Expectations:**
109: - The WebConfig class should enable CORS to allow requests from the React frontend (running on a different port).
110: - The WebConfig class should set the port to 8080 (or another suitable port).
111: - The configuration should be done using annotations (e.g., @Configuration, @EnableWebMvc, @CrossOrigin).
112: 
113: **Integration Points:**
114: - Used by the Spring Boot application to configure its behavior.
115: 
116: ## Technical Requirements
117: - Spring Boot for the backend.
118: - React for the frontend.
119: - Java 17 or higher.
120: - Maven or Gradle for dependency management.
121: - REST API design principles.
122: - CORS enabled on the backend to allow requests from the frontend.
123: - JSON for data serialization and deserialization.
124: - Use LocalDate for due dates.
125: - Use an enum for priority (HIGH, MEDIUM, LOW).
126: - Code should be well-documented and follow standard Java and JavaScript coding conventions.
127: - Use functional components and hooks in React.
128: 
129: ## Edge Cases
130: - Empty to-do list: The React frontend should display a message indicating that there are no to-do items.
131: - Invalid input: The React frontend should validate user input and display appropriate error messages if the input is invalid (e.g., missing description, invalid due date).
132: - API errors: The React frontend should handle API errors gracefully and display an error message to the user.
133: - Non-existent to-do item: The ToDoController should return a 404 Not Found error if the user tries to retrieve, update, or delete a to-do item that does not exist.
134: - Long descriptions: The React frontend should handle long descriptions gracefully (e.g., by truncating them or wrapping them).
135: - Null values: The backend should handle null values for optional fields (e.g., category) gracefully.
136: 
137: ## Acceptance Criteria
138: - [ ] When I add a new to-do item via the React UI, it should be displayed in the to-do list.
139: - [ ] When I mark a to-do item as complete via the React UI, its status should be updated in the UI.
140: - [ ] When I delete a to-do item via the React UI, it should be removed from the to-do list.
141: - [ ] When I refresh the page, the to-do list should still contain the same items (since it's in-memory).
142: - [ ] When the API returns an error, the React UI should display an appropriate error message.
143: - [ ] When I enter invalid data in the to-do form, the React UI should display validation errors.
144: - [ ] When I try to access a non-existent to-do item via the API, I should receive a 404 Not Found error.
145: - [ ] When the to-do list is empty, the React UI should display a message indicating that there are no to-do items.
146: 
```

1: # Product Requirements Document: To-Do List Application with React Frontend and Spring Boot Backend
2: 
3: ## Overview
4: This project implements a simple to-do list application. The backend is built using Spring Boot, providing a REST API for managing to-do items. The frontend is built using React, providing a user interface for interacting with the API. To-do items are stored in memory (ephemeral). Each to-do item includes a description, due date, priority, and category.
5: 
6: ## Goals
7: - User can add a new to-do item with a description, due date, priority, and category via the React UI.
8: - User can view a list of all to-do items in the React UI.
9: - User can mark a to-do item as complete via the React UI.
10: - User can delete a to-do item via the React UI.
11: - The Spring Boot backend provides a REST API to support the React UI functionality.
12: 
13: ## Non-Goals
14: - User authentication and authorization.
15: - Persistent storage of to-do items (e.g., using a database).
16: - Advanced filtering or sorting of to-do items.
17: - User accounts or profiles.
18: - Real-time updates (e.g., using WebSockets).
19: 
20: ## Components
21: 
22: ### ToDoItem Model
23: **Responsibility:** Represents a to-do item with properties like description, due date, priority, category, and completion status.
24: 
25: **Affected Files:**
26: - `src/main/java/com/example/todolist/model/ToDoItem.java`
27: 
28: **Behavior Expectations:**
29: - The ToDoItem class should have fields for id (Long), description (String), dueDate (LocalDate), priority (String), category (String), and completed (boolean).
30: - The ToDoItem class should have appropriate getters and setters for all fields.
31: - The ToDoItem class should have a constructor that accepts description, dueDate, priority, and category as arguments.
32: - Priority should be an enum with values HIGH, MEDIUM, LOW.
33: - Category should be a String.
34: 
35: **Integration Points:**
36: - Used by the ToDoService for creating, retrieving, updating, and deleting to-do items.
37: - Returned by the ToDoController as part of the REST API responses.
38: 
39: ### ToDoService
40: **Responsibility:** Provides the business logic for managing to-do items, including creating, retrieving, updating, and deleting them. Stores to-do items in an in-memory list.
41: 
42: **Affected Files:**
43: - `src/main/java/com/example/todolist/service/ToDoService.java`
44: 
45: **Behavior Expectations:**
46: - The ToDoService class should have methods for: - creating a new to-do item (createToDoItem) - retrieving all to-do items (getAllToDoItems) - retrieving a to-do item by ID (getToDoItemById) - updating a to-do item (updateToDoItem) - deleting a to-do item (deleteToDoItem)
47: - The ToDoService should use an in-memory list (ArrayList) to store the to-do items.
48: - The createToDoItem method should generate a unique ID for each new to-do item.
49: - The updateToDoItem method should update the properties of an existing to-do item.
50: - The deleteToDoItem method should remove a to-do item from the in-memory list.
51: - The getToDoItemById method should return null if no item with the given ID exists.
52: 
53: **Integration Points:**
54: - Used by the ToDoController to handle REST API requests.
55: - Uses the ToDoItem model to represent to-do items.
56: 
57: ### ToDoController
58: **Responsibility:** Handles REST API requests for managing to-do items.
59: 
60: **Affected Files:**
61: - `src/main/java/com/example/todolist/controller/ToDoController.java`
62: 
63: **Behavior Expectations:**
64: - The ToDoController should have endpoints for: - creating a new to-do item (POST /api/todos) - retrieving all to-do items (GET /api/todos) - retrieving a to-do item by ID (GET /api/todos/{id}) - updating a to-do item (PUT /api/todos/{id}) - deleting a to-do item (DELETE /api/todos/{id})
65: - The ToDoController should use the ToDoService to perform the business logic.
66: - The ToDoController should return appropriate HTTP status codes for each request (e.g., 200 OK, 201 Created, 404 Not Found).
67: - The ToDoController should serialize and deserialize ToDoItem objects to/from JSON.
68: - The POST /api/todos endpoint should return the created ToDoItem with its generated ID.
69: - The PUT /api/todos/{id} endpoint should return 404 if the item does not exist.
70: - The DELETE /api/todos/{id} endpoint should return 404 if the item does not exist.
71: 
72: **Integration Points:**
73: - Exposes the REST API for the React frontend.
74: - Uses the ToDoService to manage to-do items.
75: - Uses the ToDoItem model to represent to-do items.
76: 
77: ### React Frontend
78: **Responsibility:** Provides a user interface for interacting with the Spring Boot REST API to manage to-do items.
79: 
80: **Affected Files:**
81: - `src/main/js/App.js`
82: - `src/main/js/components/ToDoList.js`
83: - `src/main/js/components/ToDoItem.js`
84: - `src/main/js/components/ToDoForm.js`
85: 
86: **Behavior Expectations:**
87: - The App.js component should be the main entry point for the React application.
88: - The ToDoList.js component should display a list of to-do items retrieved from the API.
89: - The ToDoItem.js component should display a single to-do item and allow the user to mark it as complete or delete it.
90: - The ToDoForm.js component should allow the user to add a new to-do item.
91: - The React frontend should use the Fetch API or Axios to make requests to the Spring Boot REST API.
92: - The React frontend should handle errors gracefully (e.g., displaying an error message to the user).
93: - The React frontend should update the UI automatically when to-do items are added, updated, or deleted.
94: - The due date should be displayed in a user-friendly format.
95: - The priority should be displayed as High, Medium, or Low.
96: - The category should be displayed as a string.
97: 
98: **Integration Points:**
99: - Consumes the REST API exposed by the ToDoController.
100: - Displays to-do items to the user and allows them to interact with them.
101: 
102: ### Configuration
103: **Responsibility:** Configures the Spring Boot application, including setting the port and enabling CORS.
104: 
105: **Affected Files:**
106: - `src/main/java/com/example/todolist/config/WebConfig.java`
107: 
108: **Behavior Expectations:**
109: - The WebConfig class should enable CORS to allow requests from the React frontend (running on a different port).
110: - The WebConfig class should set the port to 8080 (or another suitable port).
111: - The configuration should be done using annotations (e.g., @Configuration, @EnableWebMvc, @CrossOrigin).
112: 
113: **Integration Points:**
114: - Used by the Spring Boot application to configure its behavior.
115: 
116: ## Technical Requirements
117: - Spring Boot for the backend.
118: - React for the frontend.
119: - Java 17 or higher.
120: - Maven or Gradle for dependency management.
121: - REST API design principles.
122: - CORS enabled on the backend to allow requests from the frontend.
123: - JSON for data serialization and deserialization.
124: - Use LocalDate for due dates.
125: - Use an enum for priority (HIGH, MEDIUM, LOW).
126: - Code should be well-documented and follow standard Java and JavaScript coding conventions.
127: - Use functional components and hooks in React.
128: 
129: ## Edge Cases
130: - Empty to-do list: The React frontend should display a message indicating that there are no to-do items.
131: - Invalid input: The React frontend should validate user input and display appropriate error messages if the input is invalid (e.g., missing description, invalid due date).
132: - API errors: The React frontend should handle API errors gracefully and display an error message to the user.
133: - Non-existent to-do item: The ToDoController should return a 404 Not Found error if the user tries to retrieve, update, or delete a to-do item that does not exist.
134: - Long descriptions: The React frontend should handle long descriptions gracefully (e.g., by truncating them or wrapping them).
135: - Null values: The backend should handle null values for optional fields (e.g., category) gracefully.
136: 
137: ## Acceptance Criteria
138: - [ ] When I add a new to-do item via the React UI, it should be displayed in the to-do list.
139: - [ ] When I mark a to-do item as complete via the React UI, its status should be updated in the UI.
140: - [ ] When I delete a to-do item via the React UI, it should be removed from the to-do list.
141: - [ ] When I refresh the page, the to-do list should still contain the same items (since it's in-memory).
142: - [ ] When the API returns an error, the React UI should display an appropriate error message.
143: - [ ] When I enter invalid data in the to-do form, the React UI should display validation errors.
144: - [ ] When I try to access a non-existent to-do item via the API, I should receive a 404 Not Found error.
145: - [ ] When the to-do list is empty, the React UI should display a message indicating that there are no to-do items.
146:

message.content: "A request was made to view the product requirements document for a To-Do List application, which outlines its components, goals, non-goals, technical requirements, edge cases, and acceptance criteria."
